articles.headline: Jobless Rate Falls to 8.3%, Altering Face of Campaign
articles.snippet: Two dueling realities — an improving economy that remains very weak — create serious political risks for top advisers to President Obama and Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Two dueling realities — an improving economy that remains very weak — create serious political risks for top advisers to President Obama and Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The burst of job growth in January gives President Obama a fresh — but tricky — opportunity to revise the grim economic narrative of his presidency while offering Mitt Romney a choice: embrace a new optimism or campaign against a sinking economy even as it shows signs of turning around.

articles.headline: Car Policy for Less, but Only if You Call
articles.snippet: A retiree qualified for lower car insurance premiums, but found that out only after a chance piece of mail prodded him to call his insurer.
articles.abstract: A retiree qualified for lower car insurance premiums, but found that out only after a chance piece of mail prodded him to call his insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: After you hear the tale of Thomas Mitchell, a retiree living in Arizona, you may suddenly have the urge to run to the phone and call your auto insurer. And perhaps even your life insurer. And your cable company. And anyone else you may do business with.

articles.headline: Obama’s Magic Number May Be 150,000 Jobs Per Month
articles.snippet: With 243,000 jobs created in January, the economy is starting to look more positive. That might be a plus for the president in the November election.
articles.abstract: With 243,000 jobs created in January, the economy is starting to look more positive. That might be a plus for the president in the November election.
articles.lead_paragraph: No economic indicator is a political holy grail. The American economy is a hard thing to measure, and initial estimates of economic performance are subject to significant revisions. Noneconomic matters — wars, candidates, scandals and so forth — matter, too.

articles.headline: Its Chief’s Big Tax Bill May Benefit Facebook
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg plans to exercise stock options with an estimated value of $5 billion ahead of Facebook’s initial public offering, which will translate into a big tax benefit for the company.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg plans to exercise stock options with an estimated value of $5 billion ahead of Facebook’s initial public offering, which will translate into a big tax benefit for the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few billionaires are willing to reveal much about their taxes.

articles.headline: Activists Fight Green Projects, Seeing U.N. Plot
articles.snippet: Suspicious of government initiatives, protesters linked to the Tea Party are denouncing all manner of measures they equate with a 1992 United Nations resolution, Agenda 21.
articles.abstract: Suspicious of government initiatives, protesters linked to the Tea Party are denouncing all manner of measures they equate with a 1992 United Nations resolution, Agenda 21.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across the country, activists with ties to the Tea Party are railing against all sorts of local and state efforts to control sprawl and conserve energy. They brand government action for things like expanding public transportation routes and preserving open space as part of a United Nations-led conspiracy to deny property rights and herd citizens toward cities.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Damascus Avoids Blood of Uprising, but Not Pain
articles.snippet: Life is growing harder in the Syrian capital, President Bashar al-Assad’s stronghold, as residents complain about electricity rationing, shortages of food and gas, and soaring prices.
articles.abstract: Life is growing harder in the Syrian capital, President Bashar al-Assad’s stronghold, as residents complain about electricity rationing, shortages of food and gas, and soaring prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The bloody uprising that has coursed through Syria has begun to upend daily life in Damascus, the stronghold of President Bashar al-Assad’s government, reordering the lives of residents who complain of hardships as simple as getting to work every day and finding bread.

articles.headline: In Fuel Oil Country, Cold That Cuts to the Heart
articles.snippet: Cuts in a federal energy-assistance program have left some families struggling to pay for oil to heat their homes.
articles.abstract: Cuts in a federal energy-assistance program have left some families struggling to pay for oil to heat their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIXFIELD, Me.

articles.headline: Russia and China Block U.N. Action on Crisis in Syria
articles.snippet: A United Nations Security Council effort to end the violence in Syria collapsed in acrimony hours after the Syrian military attacked the ravaged city of Homs.
articles.abstract: A United Nations Security Council effort to end the violence in Syria collapsed in acrimony hours after the Syrian military attacked the ravaged city of Homs.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A United Nations Security Council effort to end the violence in Syria collapsed in acrimony with a double veto by Russia and China on Saturday, hours after the Syrian military attacked the city of Homs in what opposition leaders described as the deadliest government assault in the nearly 11-month uprising.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Anthony Shadid

articles.headline: The $1.6 Billion Woman, Staying on Message
articles.snippet: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s No. 2 executive, considers herself a role model for women. But her call isn’t simply about mentoring and empowering; it’s also a business strategy.
articles.abstract: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s No. 2 executive, considers herself a role model for women. But her call isn’t simply about mentoring and empowering; it’s also a business strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: A Mortgage Tornado Warning, Unheeded
articles.snippet: Inspired by a personal experience, a businessman began delving into the practices of the mortgage industry, including Fannie Mae. His findings have been prescient.
articles.abstract: Inspired by a personal experience, a businessman began delving into the practices of the mortgage industry, including Fannie Mae. His findings have been prescient.
articles.lead_paragraph: YEARS before the housing bust — before all those home loans turned sour and millions of Americans faced foreclosure — a wealthy businessman in Florida set out to blow the whistle on the mortgage game.

articles.headline: A Wipeout That Didn’t Have to Happen
articles.snippet: An investor won an arbitration case over money lost in a complex security. But he’s still angry at financial institutions.
articles.abstract: An investor won an arbitration case over money lost in a complex security. But he’s still angry at financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOBBY L. HAYES, an engineering entrepreneur in Incline Village, Nev., used to trust financial institutions. This is the story of why he no longer does.

articles.headline: U.S. Plans Shift to Elite Units as It Winds Down in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: In ending its combat role in Afghanistan a year earlier than expected, the United States will rely more on special forces that hunt insurgent leaders and train local troops, officials say.
articles.abstract: In ending its combat role in Afghanistan a year earlier than expected, the United States will rely more on special forces that hunt insurgent leaders and train local troops, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States’ plan to wind down its combat role in Afghanistan a year earlier than expected relies on shifting responsibility to Special Operations forces that hunt insurgent leaders and train local troops, according to senior Pentagon officials and military officers. These forces could remain in the country well after the NATO mission ends in late 2014.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Gingrich Patron Could Have a Plan B: Romney
articles.snippet: The casino magnate Sheldon Adelson has relayed assurances that he will donate millions more toward defeating President Obama even if his candidate is not the nominee, associates said.
articles.abstract: The casino magnate Sheldon Adelson has relayed assurances that he will donate millions more toward defeating President Obama even if his candidate is not the nominee, associates said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino executive keeping Newt Gingrich’s presidential hopes alive, has relayed assurances to Mitt Romney that he will provide even more generous support to his candidacy if he becomes the Republican nominee, several associates said in interviews here.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Killers’ Families Left to Confront Fear and Shame
articles.snippet: In a society where headlines of violence are almost commonplace, the families of the perpetrators are largely unheard from. But now some relatives have decided to share their stories.
articles.abstract: In a society where headlines of violence are almost commonplace, the families of the perpetrators are largely unheard from. But now some relatives have decided to share their stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — On a summer night not long ago, Maureen White sat alone in her living room staring at a DVD she had avoided watching for years.

articles.headline: Romney Scores Nevada Victory With Broad G.O.P. Support
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney won handily in the Nevada caucuses with the help of groups he has struggled to persuade before, including strong Tea Party supporters and very conservative voters.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney won handily in the Nevada caucuses with the help of groups he has struggled to persuade before, including strong Tea Party supporters and very conservative voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Mitt Romney handily won the Nevada caucuses on Saturday, solidifying his status as the front-runner and increasing his momentum as he seeks to use the month of February to ease doubts within the Republican Party about his candidacy and begin confronting President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Egypt Defies U.S. by Setting Trial for 19 Americans on Criminal Charges
articles.snippet: The move is part of a politically charged investigation into the foreign financing of nonprofit groups that has shaken the 30-year alliance between the United States and Egypt.
articles.abstract: The move is part of a politically charged investigation into the foreign financing of nonprofit groups that has shaken the 30-year alliance between the United States and Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-led government said Sunday that it would put 19 Americans and two dozen others on trial in a politically charged criminal investigation into the foreign financing of nonprofit groups that has shaken the 30-year alliance between the United States and Egypt.

articles.headline: Sloan-Kettering Chief Is Accused of Taking Research
articles.snippet: The president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Dr. Craig B. Thompson, is in a billion-dollar dispute with his former workplace over accusations that he walked away with research.
articles.abstract: The president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Dr. Craig B. Thompson, is in a billion-dollar dispute with his former workplace over accusations that he walked away with research.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York is in a billion-dollar dispute with his former workplace, a cancer institute at the University of Pennsylvania, over accusations that he walked away with groundbreaking research and used it to help start a valuable biotechnology company.

articles.headline: How About Gardening or Golfing at the Mall?
articles.snippet: After decades of decline, malls across the country are being redeveloped by communities and planners trying to forge new gathering places out of vast lots with empty buildings.
articles.abstract: After decades of decline, malls across the country are being redeveloped by communities and planners trying to forge new gathering places out of vast lots with empty buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cleveland’s Galleria at Erieview, like many malls across the country, is suffering. Closed on weekends because there are so few visitors, it is down to eight retail stores, eight food-court vendors and a couple of businesses like the local bar association.

articles.headline: Significant and Silly at BuzzFeed
articles.snippet: The Web site is trying for pollination: providing the kind of content that will have visitors passing along links from one person to the next, that will in turn bring them around to BuzzFeed.
articles.abstract: The Web site is trying for pollination: providing the kind of content that will have visitors passing along links from one person to the next, that will in turn bring them around to BuzzFeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a Web site called BuzzFeed broke the news on the night of the Iowa caucuses that John McCain was endorsing Mitt Romney, more than a few readers scratched their heads and said, “What is a BuzzFeed?”

articles.headline: Print News Media Go Live With Video Programming
articles.snippet: Web sites, newspapers and other news organizations are gearing up to produce hours of video programming, in part to pursue the higher revenues available from video ads.
articles.abstract: Web sites, newspapers and other news organizations are gearing up to produce hours of video programming, in part to pursue the higher revenues available from video ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: The newest addition to the newsroom of Politico makes a statement about the news Web site’s priorities. It’s a stage set with lights, microphones, an anchor desk and five high-definition cameras so that reporters and editors can produce hours of live programming for Internet viewers.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Mobility Challenge
articles.snippet: Although more than half of its 845 million members log into Facebook on a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use.
articles.abstract: Although more than half of its 845 million members log into Facebook on a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lots of people love their cellphones. Facebook, so far, is not a big fan.

articles.headline: After a Year, Tablet Daily Is a Struggle
articles.snippet: The Daily has struggled to break into the national conversation or to drive news and build on its brand the way traditional outlets do.
articles.abstract: The Daily has struggled to break into the national conversation or to drive news and build on its brand the way traditional outlets do.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year ago Rupert Murdoch took the stage at the Guggenheim Museum and with much fanfare introduced a News Corporation publication that, in the words of the Apple executive Eddy Cue, would “redefine the news.”

articles.headline: Syrian Unrest After a Failure of Diplomacy
articles.snippet: With efforts in the United Nations failing, the Syrian government pressed on with its crackdown as some opposition leaders said force was their only option.
articles.abstract: With efforts in the United Nations failing, the Syrian government pressed on with its crackdown as some opposition leaders said force was their only option.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The collapse of diplomatic efforts to mediate Syria’s uprising reverberated across the country Sunday, emboldening a government that pressed on with a crackdown in the capital’s suburbs and the north and prompting rebel leaders to vow that only force would drive President Bashar al-Assad from power.

articles.headline: Deal Is Closer for a U.S. Plan on Mortgage Relief
articles.snippet: Potential support from California and New York would come in exchange for tightening provisions in order to preserve the right to investigate past misdeeds by the banks, and stepping up oversight.
articles.abstract: Potential support from California and New York would come in exchange for tightening provisions in order to preserve the right to investigate past misdeeds by the banks, and stepping up oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a deadline looming on Monday for state officials to sign onto a landmark multibillion-dollar settlement to address foreclosure abuses, the Obama administration is close to winning support from a crucial state that would significantly expand the breadth of the deal.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Ron Paul’s Flinty Worldview Was Forged in Early Family Life
articles.snippet: Ron Paul’s political views are unusual, and, as a closer look at his life reveals, unusually constant, shaping not only his career in Congress but also how he has lived his life.
articles.abstract: Ron Paul’s political views are unusual, and, as a closer look at his life reveals, unusually constant, shaping not only his career in Congress but also how he has lived his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: His parents married two days before the crash of 1929. He was reared on nightmarish stories of currency that proved worthless, told by relatives whose patriarch had fled Germany in the dark of night when his debts were about to ruin him.

articles.headline: Unity Deal Brings Risks for Abbas and Israel
articles.snippet: Palestinians cautiously embraced reconciliation between Hamas and Fatah, but much remains to be done, and the effect on a bid for Palestinian statehood remains unknown.
articles.abstract: Palestinians cautiously embraced reconciliation between Hamas and Fatah, but much remains to be done, and the effect on a bid for Palestinian statehood remains unknown.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority embraced reconciliation with the Islamist movement Hamas on Monday, agreeing to head a unity government to prepare for elections in the West Bank and Gaza.

articles.headline: Greece to Eliminate 15,000 Government Jobs
articles.snippet: The cuts are part of new austerity measures that Athens must agree on to secure rescue funds from international lenders.
articles.abstract: The cuts are part of new austerity measures that Athens must agree on to secure rescue funds from international lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Despite new evidence of a deteriorating economy, Greece said on Monday that it would cut 15,000 state jobs this year as part of new austerity measures it intends to adopt to secure new debt agreements from international lenders.
articles.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and David Jolly
